ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Advanced probability (literally) in the measure-theoretic sense. We first begin with a review of measure theory (that moves very quickly), then talk about product measures, weak law of large numbers and strong law of large numbers, conditional probabilities, martingales, and central limit theorem.
Probability
Measure theory basics, core results in probability theory, WLLN, CLT, and a brief overview of martingales.
probability

I gained a much deeper understanding of probability theory. I came into the course after having taken several probability theory courses in undergrad (6+  years ago) and self-studying real analysis the summer before this course started. Candidly, I was nervous how much of the course I could follow, but I generally felt that I could follow along with all the concepts in the course (although it often also involved a decent bit of self-studying before and after each class). The final project showed me that these concepts are relevant and ubiquitous in understanding any kind of probability paper, and I feel more confident now than before that I can tackle a much greater range of probability papers than before I had taken this course.
Measure theory for statistics.
Thorough development of measure theory followed by revisiting important results in probability, generalized over infinite spaces via our new analytic tool set.
I now understand the construction of the Lebesgue measure and have demystified measure theoretic probability
Review of basic measure and integration theory. First time exposure to martingales and measure theoretic conditional expectation and markov kernels. Sharpened skills in probability theory.
I learned a lot in this course. I was able to expand my knowledge of Real Analysis and Proof-based exercise, and it helped me rethink probability theory completely.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Problem sets can be unnecessarily tedious

Strengths are Sekhar's lectures; the proofs are surprisingly clear and pretty well motivated, and Sekhar has a good sense of humor. The problem sets, while challenging, also helped to build upon the material we learned in class (and provided further motivation for things you might have learned in 241). Only weakness is that we didn't get to cover some cool topics (like Brownian motion and large deviations), but that's more of a consequence of being a 1-semester course. I hope to see Sekhar's "Topics on Probability" course approved in the near future...
The lecture note is not quite readable for me

I think this course attracts a diverse array of mathematical backgrounds, which can make it difficult at times to build a cohesive progression of material. That said, I greatly appreciated the current coverage of the course.

My only complaint with the course is that there isn't a part 2 to the course. It was clear towards the end that there were still a lot of interesting topics to cover (e.g., large deviations), and we wouldn't have time to cover those. Otherwise, I thought the course was very well structured. We spent a roughly optimal amount of time on measure theory (as someone who self-studied real analysis and knew no measure theory coming into the class) to have all the tools we needed to cover the probability concepts, and while all the theory behind conditional probability was challenging, it was helpful that we immediately tackled martingales as an application for conditional probabilities. Otherwise, the problem sets were roughly the right difficulty/length/frequency. I'm not really sure how we could have improved on those. I will note that office hours were absolutely critical to working through the problem sets. I often found that my solutions coming into the office hours were not quite right, so they were crucial to making sure that I actually understood the concepts properly.
Very useful course for theory statistics.
The instructor is great, lectures are entertaining, TAs are knowledgeable and provide thorough feedback on assignments, which are challenging and numerous.

Instructor is very good and able to really clearly convey difficult concepts. The course is almost all self contained in the sense that every result can be proved with things priorly shown in the course. This makes everything have a satisfying feeling of connectivity. The only "weakness" was the speed at which lectures moved which necessitated individual study ... but I do not think it is fair to call that a weakness in a graduate course.
The course is strong in its speed and depth. While the notes are indeed legible, a scribe would be appreciated.

Stregths are the choice of the textbooks, the content selection and the rigorosity.

Weaknesses are that some problem sets may be a bit too long. I learned a lot from them though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, assuming you have the appropriate pre-requisites. If you don't have previous exposure to ideas in measure theory (not necessarily Math 320/520, but at least knowledge of the Lebesgue measure, and the "major" results of monotone convergence, dominated convergence, and Fatou's), the first part of the class will be VERY fast, even for someone who has seen the material before.

I would recommend to anyone looking for more theoretical grounding of probability. This is very much NOT an applied course, and serves primarily to deepen ones understanding of what probability is, not how to use probability in other contexts.
Yes, to those who are very interested in math, probability, and proof
Yes, learn probability

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to any student who is interested in learning measure-theoretic probability theory. It should be well-designed, approachable, and interesting to any student with that interest. That being said, I would absolutely not recommend this to any student who is not interested in working through a lot of proofs.
Yes. Very useful and challenging course.

Yes as long as the student is very confident they'd enjoy the material. I took the class because I enjoyed math 305 and thought this would be an interesting extension, but I did not particularly love the content. Sekhar though is really excellent and just a great guy and a pretty clear instructor. The final project was also very rewarding and it's super nice not having exams
Yes! It takes a lot of effort to get comfortable with new math, this class is no exception.
If they want to understand probability intimately and love math ... yes.
Yes. It is a good first course in measure theoretic probability.
Yes! I would recomend this course to any student wanting to do theory in Economics.
